title: Battery pack for Lafayett DC-155 micro 3+

description.text:
Made this battery pack for a friends hunting radio.
The battery cells was bad. Could have bought a new battery pack but how fun is that.
Original pack has six R03/AAA cells. This box is made to fit six R6/AA cells.
The original pack can be seen in some of the pictures.
I welded the new batteries together including a thermostat of the same type that is used in the original.
The top/lid is meant to be glued on once the batteries are installed.
I cut two pices out of a brass plates to act as contacts and soldered wires between the batteries and plates. Included a insulation board for good measure although I do not think it is needed as the batteries fit very snug. This was my first ever 3D creation attempt and the box could have been made better looking. Funktion is ok though. Slides in and out of the radio just like the original and my friend has used it for a couple of months now without any problems.

Dremel 3D IDEA BUILDER

title: xItaly by DeeBee.it - weareable xDrip for Dexcom

description.text:
This is the first case in the world for xDrip to be used as a charm, due to its small dimensions.
You can put your xDrip inside xItaly charm, to obtain a really small receiver for Dexcom G4 transmitter.
You can then use xItaly paired to a 3G smartwatch: in this way signal will never be lost!
Look here: http://www.deebee.it/?p=1741 1) Purchare a 500mAh LiPo battery: https://www.adafruit.com/product/1578
2) Build your own xDrip circuit (HM-11 version without Battery plug): http://stephenblackwasalreadytaken.github.io/xDrip/
3) Put xDrip inside the xItaly and close with glue: http://www.deebee.it/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/xitaly-steps.jpg
DONE! You can ask for xItaly here: [email protected]
Designed in Italy. ITALIANO
Questo è il primo dispositivo indossabile a mo' di ciondolo, date le ridotte dimensioni, che al suo interno ospita xDrip.
Con xItaly puoi ricevere le glicemie del sensore Dexcom senza usare il ricevitore ufficiale.
Puoi usare xItaly insieme ad uno smartwatch GSM: in questo modo avrai un sistema discreto e non perderai mai il segnale!
Qui l'articolo completo: http://www.deebee.it/?p=1741 1) Acquista una batteria da 500mAh: https://www.adafruit.com/product/1578
2) Costruisci il tuo xDrip con la guida riportata nel gruppo italiano https://www.facebook.com/groups/1535088246753506/ (la versione con chip HM-11 e senza attacco per la batteria).
3) Inserisci xDrip dentro xItaly e chiudi il guscio con la colla, così: http://www.deebee.it/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/xitaly-steps.jpg
FINE! Puoi stampare xItaly presso un qualsiasi servizio di stampa 3D oppure puoi procurartelo qui: http://www.shapeways.com/shops/papancreas xItaly è un progetto italiano.

This is a Remix of Spikeys Model but with a stand.

Printer:

Reprap Build

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1-0.2mm

Infill:

50-100%

Notes: I recommend printing it in two parts (splitted in the middle of the model) and with supports for the stand.

Here is a short manual of how i placed the model on my print bred in two halves. 1.) Place the model on the print bed with one part of the stand touching the bed (as you can see in the picture of the slicing program)
2.) Measure the height
3.) Move down the model by the half of the height
4.) Copy and mirror
5.) Arrange both sides
6.) Done I am using Simplify 3D, so the steps may vary at your slicing program.

A full setup for the E3d Chimera with tilt mechanism by a servo mounted on the X carriage. Feel free to edit, Google Sketchup file included! Any suggestions/changes/updates are most welcome. Google Sketchup file has Dynamic components to animate the rotation. Just for fun..

  • I used two 6703 ZZ 17MM X 23MM X 4MM bearings. The part which goes into the bearings inner ring is quite tight measured, so adjust as needed as every printer prints slightly different. The goal is to squeeze it in really tight so it clamps and has no play.
    Same counts for the outer ring to the X carriage. It's quite tightly measured to fit with no play at all. The idea is to squeeze (hammer ;) ) the X carriage over the bearing's outer ring so it fits very tight. There is no clamp to hold the outer ring in place in the X carriage, it's only by tight fit.

  • Servo used is a standard 9g micro servo. Be aware, dimensions of inner hole covering servo spline are not accurate and need adjustment, no spline teeth included in small gear inner hole as every servo is different and spline is too detailed for the printer i thought.

  • Belt clamp/holder is for T2.5 belt, but can off course be edited in sketchup.
  • Tilt of chimera is 5 deg left/right. Gear system makes servo rotate 45 degrees left or right to rotate chimera 5 degrees left or right.

  • X carriage is made for Sunhokey Prusa I3, but you can edit for your own machine.

  • Anything else i forgot to mention?
    • Any questions, ask! More later... -- This thing is a work in progress -- UPDATE : Took a while, but now printed and installed. All measurements are correct, but you might have to fine tune here and there for your printer.
    Tilt mechanism works, and needs very small modification of the marlin main code.
    Tilting works like a charm. Chimera is held perfectly in place without any play in any direction. Very tight fit of the bearings worked out perfect. Next todo is bend the heat break tubes 5 degrees (not done yet). and install the two small metal plates under the x carriage.
  • Tilting arm increased in size to make it much more rigid, now chimera sits in place solid as a rock.

  • Induction sensor moved a little to give way to heater cartridge wires.

  • Marlin_main.cpp code modification : add the bold small paragraph of code in the tool change code.

/** * T0-T3: Switch tool, usually switching extruders** * * F[mm/min] Set the movement feedrate */ inline void gcode_T(uint8_t tmp_extruder) { if (tmp_extruder >= EXTRUDERS) { SERIAL_ECHO_START; SERIAL_CHAR('T'); SERIAL_PROTOCOL_F(tmp_extruder, DEC); SERIAL_ECHOLN(MSG_INVALID_EXTRUDER); } else { //Added for Chimera tilt dual extruder if (active_extruder != tmp_extruder){ st_synchronize(); if(tmp_extruder == 0) { servo[EXTRUDER_SERVO].attach(EXTRUDER_SERVO_PIN); servo[EXTRUDER_SERVO].move(SERVOPOS_E0); delay (SERVO_DELAY); servo[EXTRUDER_SERVO].detach(); } if(tmp_extruder == 1) { servo[EXTRUDER_SERVO].attach(EXTRUDER_SERVO_PIN); servo[EXTRUDER_SERVO].move(SERVOPOS_E1); delay(SERVO_DELAY); servo[EXTRUDER_SERVO].detach(); } } //end Chimera tilt dual extruder target_extruder = tmp_extruder; #if EXTRUDERS > 1 bool make_move = false; #endif if (code_seen('F')) { #if EXTRUDERS > 1 make_move = true; #endif float next_feedrate = code_value(); if (next_feedrate > 0.0) feedrate = next_feedrate; }
• And add this somewhere in your configuration.h

#define EXTRUDER_SERVO 0 // Defines which servo is used for tilting the extruder #if (EXTRUDER_SERVO == 0) #define EXTRUDER_SERVO_PIN SERVO0_PIN #endif #if (EXTRUDER_SERVO == 1) #define EXTRUDER_SERVO_PIN SERVO1_PIN #endif #if (EXTRUDER_SERVO == 2) #define EXTRUDER_SERVO_PIN SERVO2_PIN #endif #if (EXTRUDER_SERVO == 3) #define EXTRUDER_SERVO_PIN SERVO3_PIN #endif #define SERVOPOS_E0 99 #define SERVOPOS_E1 99 #define SERVO_DELAY 1000

comments.text: Can I suggest you use Sketchup to save it in an older Sketchup format... every new version of Sketchup blocks older versions from actually reading the files... so, for example, only the latest version (2016) can actually read it.  If you simply use the "Save As" function, you can save it as a Sketchup 8 version file, which doesn't loose anything, but is actually able to read by most versions of Sketchup.

description.text:
Pour faire un don pour m'aider à faire les tests des pièces : https://www.paypal.me/DavidDal Modèle spécifique Dagoma D200 avec capteur, utiliser le capteur pour la mise en place, repiquage du ventilo sur celui déjà en place ( permet de moduler ) Le modèle 03 est spécifique pour la buse e3d
Le modèle 06 est une modification du premier fonctionnant avec les buses e3d ainsi que S1 avec un meilleur guidage de l' air.La modification pour la tête S1 ayant été réalisée avec l' aide de Picaboubx, propriétaire de ce modèle de tête. edit 2016/08 :
Ajout du fichier blocage Direct Drive Dagoma.STL fourni par Thomas, propriétaire de ce modèle de tête, qui as eu besoin de modifier la pièce pour permettre son montage sur la nouvelle tête
(direct drive dagoma, que perso, j' aurai nommé 3D mais je suis pas leur commercial et comme je trouve dommage de pas utiliser cette opportunité d'avoir un nom qui reflète l'usage, j' ai fait ma propre tête 3D : Direct Drive DAL \o/ et même un modèle en 4D .... mieux qu' au futuroscope ) ATTENTION:
Pour le modèle 06 les trous de vis du bas sont aveugle d'une profondeur de 6.5 mm

title: Small 35 mL dual wall vessel for liquid nitrogen

description.text:
This is a small 35 mL dual wall vessel which shows pretty good thermal resistance. To make it 3D printable, I added a small support in the center, so the printer makes two perimeters at once. One support was not enough however to hold the internal cup during the printing, so I added another circular support in the middle.
Planning to try making real 3D printable Dewar flask (aka Thermos), with vacuum between the walls. But even with the air there, the vessel provides pretty good thermal insulation.
On the photo, there is liquid nitrogen inside the cup - the surface is cold, maybe below zero centigrade, but I did not get a frostbite after holding it for 10-15 min which it takes for the N2 to evaporate completely.
Useful as a tiny cooling/heating bath for lab.

MR angiography (MRA) is a technique to visualize blood vessels. I extracted the vascular structures (arteries) and after minor editing, printed it.

Prusa i3

Notes: The best support making application for this kind of models is Meshmixer

Coloring and after print treatment I used DCM to smooth the model and also strengthen it. Afterwards, I colored it to red to implement "artery".
I installed the model on a wooden plate by acrylate glue.

comments.text: I tried to make one of these it didn't seem to come out right. Is the orientation that it's shown above the ideal way to print this? My impression is that there is some overhang in the design. Is this correct? Are there any other tricks to it?
comments.author: fishbulb2

comments.text:
For sure, this can not be printed right away. If you are familiar with Meshmixer, first analize and fine best orientation (set overhang angle at 25). Accept that orientation and save it. Then use "generate support". Play a little bit with the settings until you can get the best result.
Without the supports of Meshmixer style, it is hard to get a nice clean print.

description.text: They made war upon the Barrens, where wood is scarce and bones bloom eternal. --Qie Zi, The Art of Seej The Battle Flag, Charnel introduces a new player race for Seej: The Barrow Lords! A player fielding a charnel battle flag may right one toppled flag for every three barrow bloxen in his fortification. I designed the charnel battle flag to really push the FDM printability envelope. One can print this banner with support, but one shouldn't have to. It's a one piece print, unlike previous Seej battle flags. The vertebrae at the bottom of the flag can be a little tricky, so make sure your build platform is quite level. This particular flag is printed on a Replicator1 with Filabot's recycled ABS filament and then dipped in black tempera paint to bring out the details and give it a little grime.

The wheels where painted black to hide the seam.

Our fridge door sometimes doesn't close completely. To become aware of a not correctly closed door immediately (instead of after a night) I created this open-door-detector.
As a side effect you also get a beep-notification when making your choice while the door is open takes too long ;-) The door open detection is done by a micro switch. It closes on opening the door and thereby provides power to the circuit which contains an Arduino based microcontroller (ATmega328) and a spare piezo speaker. Note that instead of a complete Arduino board only the Atmega328P is used on a breadboard. See the clip by Julian Ilett on how to do this. (But I needed an extra 10 kOhm pullup on the reset pin 1 during data transfer.) The file "ArduinoToneMelody.ino" contains the program:
  • On opening the door the LED starts to blink.
  • After 10, 20 and 30 seconds the program will do 1, 2 and 3 beeps respectively.
  • After 40, 50 and 60 seconds a siren sound will be repeated once, twice and thrice respectively.
  • After 70, 80 and 90 seconds a short melody plays.
  • Then all steps will be repeated.
    • See the circuit picture for used parts.
  • The Atmega328P was bought with Arduino bootloader programmed which simplifies getting started.
  • The piezo-speaker was taken from a broken device.
  • The microswitch closes when the fridge door opens. So the circuit needs no current while the fridge door is closed. It is soldered onto a piece of veroboard only to provide stability.
    • OpenSCAD files are included. (Including my own battery-box-design.)

title: Styracosaurus albertensis
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This model of a dinosaur, Styracosaurus albertensis, is my first foray into 3D printing! I come from a background in video games as a modeler, sculptor, and texture artist. Styracosaurus albertensis was a centrosaurine dinosaur - an older cousin of the better-known Triceratops - that lived in the Cretaceous period. Its remains have been found in the Dinosaur Park Formation in Alberta. It can be distinguished with its impressive nasal horn and spikes running along the upper portion of its frill. It is estimated to have weighed three tons and been around the size of a very large rhinoceros. Many paleontologists theorize that between a specialized set of scissor-like teeth and a sharp beak, Styracosaurus, along with many other ceratopsians, ate cycads and palms. This model was made in Blender and sculpted in Mudbox. Its polycount has been lowered for print.
Render of full resolution model with PBR textures. Muscle reconstruction Muscle reconstruction

I used Cura to generate the gcode. I tried to print it multiple times, but it failed. It printed the raft for the right front foot, then moved to the left front foot, and tried to print way above the bed. Then it went back to the 1st foot area, and started a little cylinder. Then back to the other foot and printed way above the bed. Ended up with a start of a raft, and a small ball of filament every time I tried. I went back to Cura, rotated the model and tried again, with the same results.
I am new to 3D printing, and maybe I had the setup wrong.
Pete

description.text:
This is the extruder bracket for the Prusa i3 Pro X from Geeetech, labelled as piece i3B1-30. 
I reverse engineered it and added a hole for the use of an induction sensor. In this case an LJ18A3-8-Z/BX with a detecting distance of ~8mm. This will enable auto levelling of your print bed assuming that correct software and detectable metal is installed/used.
These files were created with laser cutting in mind as I did with mine, however they can simply be extruded up 8mm to achieve the correct thickness if you're going to print. I used two stuck together when I cut them out as I only had 4mm Perspex.

I used tire balancing weights which you can get from amazon for next to nothing, or you could fill the bottom tier with jewelry for your intended recipient. I left the K on the front of the tier 3 here but if you don't want that then simply print 2 tier ones and rotate one 180 to act as tier 3. title: DIY Wifi Laser cutter and engraver with 3D printed parts

description.text:
Variant of the DIY laser cutter from smartDIYs using 3D printed parts. Assembly is similar as http://en.smartdiys.com/smart-laser-mini/ but cutting area is bigger 330*330 mm I have used black open builds 500mm extrusion for y-axis and x-axis, frame is assembled using two additional 430mm beams. I have bought the extrusion and all mechanical parts in europe at http://www.ratrig.com/
Quality is great! I have created simple 80mm feet and a holder for the laser to fit to 70mm beam fitted on x-axis. In addition you will find the stepper, idler and plate that need to be printed 3 times each. Electronics use Arduino Uno clone with GRBL shield V3.0 and 3 A4988 drivers. Power distribution and keyboard/led board done with Adafruit perma-proto PCBs and UBEC.
The Arduino runs the GRBL V0.9g firmware with mr-beam fork.
The arduino is connected to a raspberry pi running Octopi modified for Mr Beam laser cutter to allow operation over wifi. See Mr Beam page for how to download these great software Laser diode is M140 2W 445nm driven by TTL driver. All wires are protected by a printed cable chain (Thing 34661).
Endstops are fixed thru holes drilled in the stepper and idler plates Any questions feel free to use the comment button

comments.text: I went back to the BOM and figured out my source of confusion. I had read 1x430mm (which could only be the x-rail) and not 2x430mm (which can be the x-frame axis). As a result I was trying to figure out how a 430mm x-rail attached to two carriage plates which were attached to rails 500mm apart. The answer is, of course, you don't, and can't. Now that I re-read the BOM, it does say, 2x430mm, which provides 2x70mm, and a span of 430mm for a single 500mm x-carriage rail. Which, of course, does fit.

description.text: I found this design scurrying around down at the bottom of my hard drive. If I remember right this was a design that I did up right quick to satisfy the pre-rec so I could take the classes to get my drafting certification. This quad was designed to press-fit mount 380 size STANDARD car motors and hold a 1300mah 3 cell LiPoly pack. Although the motor pods do fit on the ends of the arms quite snugly a dab of glue wouldn't hurt ta just keep em on there good an tight. You'll also need 8 small bolts (sorry, don't remember the size of these) and you'll also need a couple of bolts with wingnuts or thumbscrews for the battery strap. Assembly requires that the arms go in-between the chassis plates. NOTE The motor pods have a hole at the bottom for motor wires to lead through but this may be too small for some wire packs but I'll fix this as soon as I get the chance after break.

Save those fingers and eyes new years eve when ligthing the fireworks. With this ligther on a stick you can light up the fireworks at a distance, enhancing your chances of getting safe into the coming year.
And don't forget those glasses either...!

You will need:
  • Ligther, Zenga ZL-1
  • 2mm stainless steel tig welding rod, coat hanger wire, or something similar. You might get away with a piece of string.
  • A piece of 22mm round wood
  • Some wood screws ~3x16mm
    • Assembly is mostly self explanatory, it is crucial that the moving parts can move freely, so make sure to clean them up.

It's a carousel designed to hold 6 photos of 10x15cm It's made of 29 parts, most of them take more than 5H to print
You also need 6 glass pane (10x15cm) and a lot of glue Parts list :
4 x socle_part.stl or 1 x socle.stl
4 x chapiteau_part.stl or 1 x chapiteau.stl
6 x colonne.stl
6 x cadre.stl
6 x couvercle_cadre.stl
1 x axe.stl
1 x rondelle_bas.stl
1 x rondelle_haut.stl Instructions :
Glue the 4 socle_part and the axe together.
Glue the 4 chapiteau_part together.
Glue a glass pane inside each couvercle_cadre
Glue each couvercle_cadre to a cadre
Screw each cadre to rondelle_bas (bottom) and rondelle_haut (top)
Glue a colonne between each cadre
Screw the chapiteau to the set of cadres

description.text:
This is a container system based on 2-1/2 Trade Size PVC conduit.  Cut conduit to length, and add whatever combination of caps and connectors you choose.  I designed it originally as a cheap alternative to hold welding rod, and keep it clean. It can of course be scaled to fit just about any size tube, but you'll need do the math for your particular application.
Each part has the option of no loops, one loop, or two loops depending on how you want to secure the individual parts.  For removable caps, you can bungee/tie between the two ends, glue one or the other to the tube and leave the other free, or glue a retaining anchor in a convenient location on the tube, and tether to that for securing that particular end.

title: Chimera / Cyclops Prusa i3 mount (with print fans and proximity sensor supports)

description.text: Support is designed from zero but inspired in invent0r great design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:661185, it was made before he published his rework: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1216890 which is also amazing. In fact if you guys are not interested in mounting FAN for the print or proximity sensor yo should use his, cause is way cooler. Having said that, I used to have an e3dv6, and while moving to chimera i found some good designs out there that offer either proximity sensor OR fans for the print, but i couldn0't find one simple enough that incorporated both. (if inventor had published his rework before i would probably just have edited his design :D. the source is made in Freecad, so I'm also posing the source in case you guys want to rework for your own needs. There was a difficulty on the original designs all over and it was the difficulty to remove the bowden tubes because the fittings are down below (you would need a screwdriver or something to actually push the fitting while pull the tube) so i designed a fitting adapter (you can see it in the pictures). STL and freecad source posted. Also, you will notice that the design has side slots. Those are for inserting security bowden clips I designed (also posting the stl and the freecad source). I originally used this clips with my e3dv6: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668232, and they work great to ensure your bowden tube stays well in position and no movement at all. Unfortunately, that clip wouldn't work with this design so i created some new ones, nevertheless, some credit must go to WheelbarrowTech for the idea. BTW, you need to make sure the tube is well seated all the way down while inserting the clips. I'm also posting the fan grids (made in this customizer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:735449) and the STL of the fan duct, which took from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:510957 and made a very slight adjustment for my e3d v6 mount, so i actually just used them in this design (they work extremely well so.. nothing to reinvent there :) thanks to shuttl3d for that design) please let me know if you have any questions! :)

title: Dog Cone Clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Imagine a world where you are a dog owner with two dogs. Your one dog is slightly neurotic and likes to lick his paws a lot, which causes you to have to apply the "Cone of Shame" treatment. After a while, your other dog decides that the cone treatment has gone on long enough, and decides to vindicate the enconed pup. Ultimately, the cone resists the attempts and stay firmly in place, but loses 3 of the 5 clips that hold it in together. I designed this replacement part in Tinkercad (tinkercad.com) and is my VERY FIRST thing I've ever designed and contributed. Go easy on the design :)

I've printed out a few tests of it on my modded cupcake, and it requires some fine tuning of the profile. My best rendition has been using ABS with 0 extra shells and 20% infill ratio with 2 shells for solid surface thickness. I set SF's Cool to 15 seconds per layer (stock in most of the TOM profiles). The only major issue with the design is the original pieces are injection molded using what I can only assume is HDPE, and is much more flexible than ABS. This makes using these replacement difficult to put on and remove the cone from the dog.

comments.text: I've got one of those neurotic dogs too and so I take the cone off and on to give him a break during the time I can watch him.  Doing that also causes these clips to break.  I had some of the NinjaTek Cheetah material on hand and gave it a try.  It appears to work great.  I initially thought that it might be too flexible but it snaps in and out and seems to hold so far.  It hasn't been on the dog for too long but so far so good.  I'll post if it later fails but if you don't see anything, then you can assume that its working.  Thanks a lot for your design!!

author: PD1MF

title: Reptar XY! (Improved blocks for the Ultimaker)

description.text:
After building up and modifying some of MoonCactus' great XY blocks, I realized that although the design was spectacular functionally, it was about equally as challenging to assemble as the stock UM XY blocks. So while trying to maintain the major benefits of the original (integrated adjustability, low profile, removable without taking out the 8mm axes) I set out to redesign them - with improved assembly and accessibility. The result is the Reptar XY block, a strong, easy-to-print, easy to assemble, highly functional XY bushing block... which was designed almost in its entirety before I printed it in purple and green and embraced the fact that it looked like a dinosaur. ...Anyway, like I said, it offers some big usability improvements:

  • The Main body (green part) snap-fits onto the bronze bushing and the 6mm rod, holding them captive - which means you can assemble most of it without any screwing, and then add screws later to make everything secure.

  • All of the screws are accessible from the front side, including the tension adjustment screw. This is a very nice feature and makes assembly much more enjoyable

  • The bronze bushing does not get deformed as you tighten things up

  • The limit switch 'spikes' are a separate part, which means you print 4 of the same assemblies and just screw the 2 limit spikes to the appropriate XY blocks - less files to manage.
    • The necessary non-printed parts per block:

  • 3x #2 x 0.5" Torx Drive Plastite Screws (+1x when installing the limit switch spikes) (McMaster P/N: 99512A162)

  • 2x #2 x 0.75" Torx Drive Plastite Screws (Mcmaster P/N: 96001A164)

  • 2x Aluminum Standoff ( McMaster P/N: 94669A612)
    • 2013.08.20 - v1.16 Update: I've uploaded the latest STL files, after printing several dozen of these and installing them on 3 machines. I now believe, however, that a combined XY block + tensioning mechanism is not necessarily the best path forward (see comments) and will be redesigning this in order to simplify it further. 2013.08.06 - v1.16 Changelog: Added small tabs to locate the bushings! 2013.07.31 - v1.15 Changelog: Changed the shape of the clamp jaw to get better clamping and a cleaner print. Parametric files only at the moment, I'll upload STLs when I get a little more testing in. 2013.07.30 - v1.14 Changelog: Updated switch trigger clearance. There will now need to be two separate parts for this, unfortunately. Uploading the longer one soon. Made some improvements to the tensioning mechanism as well as the clamping. Parametric files only at the moment, I'll upload STLs when I get a little more testing in.

Print each piece at 0.1mm layers or thinner, no brim, no raft, no support!  The main body (green in the photos) should be printed on it's back (with the axis of the 6mm rod semicylinder pointing upwards).  
The purple clamp body should have the axis of 6mm rod semicylinder parallel to the bed, with that face down. The print lines should be clear in my photo.

comments.text: While it is true they would be stronger printed on their side, printing on their backs provides a uniform set of conditions when printing the axis contact surfaces - resulting in a better alignment of parts when everything is installed. Though it is possible to break them in this orientation, once they are installed they seem to be more more than strong enough - so I think prioritizing alignment/accuracy over maximized strength is warranted here.
comments.author: destroyer2012

comments.text: I don't understand what you mean by "uniform set of conditions". Are you talking about z-axis artifacts? What kinds of alignment effects do you expect?
comments.author: nhfoley

comments.text: Well, printed on it's side, half of the 6mm rod contact surface is going to be printed as an overhang, while the lower half won't. Even though the overhang is minimal, it's still not going to print a perfect circle in this orientation - and then when you print the block for the other side, it's going to be deviating from circular also, but in the opposite direction, unless you rotate the part 180° before printing. This just seems like a complication because it is introducing unnecessary asymmetry and probably reducing the contact surface with the 6mm rod. It also makes getting the snap-fit of the 6mm rod more tedious.

This is a remix.  Used Airtight Filament Storage/ Dispenser II as a basis for the box, but re designed the feed throughs based on Universal Filament Filter by CreativeTools to incorporate both a feed thru and a filter in one.  The Cross Section stl shows the interior is designed to hold a piece of foam, and guide the filament to the exit hole.  A drop of mineral oil will help lube the filament.
I included the 123Design file so if your box wall is thicker or thinner, you can adjust the c-clip slot. My wall was about 2mm thick.
BE CAREFUL making the holes in the box.  mine shattered when I tried to drill out the holes, so I used a soldering iron with a blade tip to cut the holes.

A "separation" remote head mount for the Yaesu FT-857D. Final version. This version uses a "bump" on the end to keep the head in place. It also has holes on the top and bottom to mount to a desk, unlike the Yaesu version. Of course, this is also about five times larger than the Yaesu version, but it is working very well for me. Note: Some people are saying that their remote head fits differently. This model fits quite well on mine, but you may have issues. The OEM head mount must somehow take this into consideration, so if you have modifications please post them to thingiverse and let me know so I can link to it. TinkerCad URL: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hmu7GXkKELc-ft-857-separation-mount-v8 This cable might work for the connection to the radio. If anybody tries one, please let me know how it works. http://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/AT-S-26-6%2F6%2FB-25/A1662R-25-ND/1972704 73 de K5EHX
